ORDER

This is a petition filed under Section 482 of the Code
of Criminal Procedure for quashing the proceedings pending
against the petitioner in S.C. No. 177 of 2018 on the files of the
Assistant Sessions Court, Karunagappally.

2. The petitioner is the third accused in Crime No.
67 of 2012 of Sasthamcotta Police Station registered under
Sections 452 and 511 of 376 read with Section 34 of the
Indian Penal Code. There were altogether four accused in the
said case. The petitioner was not available at the time of the
committal proceedings. Consequently, the case was committed
for trial as against accused Nos.1, 2 and 4. During the
pendency of the proceedings before the trial court, the first
accused committed suicide. Proceedings in the circumstances,
was continued against accused Nos.2 and 4. The trial court
found the accused guilty of offences punishable under
Sections 452 and 354 read with Section 34 of Indian Penal
Code and convicted them. Accused Nos. 2 and 4 challenged
the decision of the trial court in Crl.A. No. 20 of 2018.

ante
2020/KER/499

Crl.M.C. No. 8275 of 2019

Annexure 4 is the judgment in the said case. In terms of the

said judgment, the appellate court found that the evidence of

the prosecutrix who was examined as PW1 was not reliable and

that therefore, there cannot be any conviction based on the

said evidence. Consequently, accused Nos. 2 and 4 were
acquitted. In the meanwhile, the petitioner appeared before

the committal court and consequently the case against him

was also committed for trial as S.C. No. 177 of 2018. The
petitioner seeks orders to quash the said proceedings on the
ground that in the light of the decision in Crl.A. No.20 of 2018,

the proceedings now pending against him is an abuse of the
process of the Court as no purpose whatsoever would be
served by the said proceedings.

3. Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner as
also the learned Public Prosecutor.

4. The essence of the finding, on the basis of which
accused Nos.2 and 4 were acquitted by the appellate court,
contained in paragraph 16 of the judgment reads thus:

“16. On analysing the evidence of PW1, the
prosecutrix, it is found that her testimony is inconsistent
with her earlier version in Ext.P1 on material aspects.
The fact that PW1 had not suffered any bodily injury

ante
2020/KER/499
Crl.M.C. No. 8275 of 2019
though she allegedly resisted violent rape attempt by
four adult persons is a suspicious circumstance. There
are material discrepancies and contradictions in the
testimony of PW1. Infirmities of this nature would not
have occurred in the testimony of PW1 if she was
speaking true facts. There is no ring of the truth in the
testimony of PW1. The delay of six days is not properly
explained. In view of the infirm nature of the evidence of
PW1, this Court is view that it is not safe to rely on her
testimony. In the said circumstances it is held that the
prosecution has failed to prove that the accused have
committed the offences alleged against them. Point is
thus held against the prosecution and it is held that the
conviction and sentence of the court below is not legally
sustainable.”
It is seen that the case against the accused in both cases is
built on the statement of PW1. Insofar as it is found that the
said statement is not reliable and that there cannot be any
conviction based on the same, according to me, the
substratum of the case is lost.
5. If that be so, in the light of the decision of this
Court in Moosa v. Sub Inspector of Police (2006 (1) KLT
552), no purpose whatsoever would be served by directing the
petitioner to face the trial, and the trial against the petitioner
would only be a futile exercise, resulting in wastage of precious
